summary.para: Contains classes for DevExpress Blazor components.
Lists values that specify where the Accordion component displays its expand button.
The Accordion displays an expand button to the right of items.
The Accordion does not display an expand button.
The Accordion displays an expand button to the left of items.
Lists actions that can expand or collapse an Accordion item.
When item selection is disabled, users can click an item or its Expand/Collapse button to expand/collapse the item.
When item selection is enabled, users can click an item header to select it or the Expand/Collapse button to expand/collapse the item.
The item expands or collapses when a user clicks the expand\collapse button.
The item expands or collapses when a user clicks the item’s header or expand\collapse button.
The item expands or collapses when a user double clicks the item’s header or expand\collapse button.
Lists values that specify how many Accordion items can be expanded at a time.
Users can expand multiple items. At least one item is always expanded.
Users can expand multiple items or collapse all items.
One item is always expanded.
Users can expand one item or collapse all items.

Casts arguments/values to the type and displays them on the Discrete axis.

summary.para: Lists values that specify how the chart displays axis labels.
Rotates axis labels at the angle specified by the property.
Arranges axis labels in two staggered rows. Use the property to specify the empty space between rows.
Does not change the default arrangement of axis labels.
Lists formats applied to axis and series labels.
Displays numbers as a billion (1 000 000 000.11 → 1B).
Adds a currency symbol to a number (3.95 → $3.95).
Displays a current day (for example, 01).
Displays a day of the week (for example, Thursday).
Displays a decimal number (100.11 → 100).
Label values are not formatted.
Displays a number in exponential notation (1 000 → 1E+3).
Displays a number with a fixed point.
Displays hours (for example, 12).
Uses “Thousands”, “Millions”, “Billions”, or “Trillions” format depending on the actual value.
Displays a date in the dddd, MMMM dd, yyyy format (for example, Thursday, January 01, 1970).
Displays a date-time value in the dddd, MMMM dd, yyyy, hh:mm:ss format (for example, Thursday, January 01, 1970, 12:00:00 AM).
Displays a time value in the hh:mm:ss format (for example, 12:00:00 AM).
Displays numbers as a million (1 000 000.11 → 1M).
Displays milliseconds (for example, 010).
Displays time in minutes (for example, 00).
Displays months (for example, January).
Displays a date in the MMMM dd format (for example, January 01).
Displays a date in the yyyy MMMM format (for example, 1970 January)
Displays numbers as percentile values (for example, 0.1 → 10%).
Displays a quarter of the year for a date (for example, QI).
Displays a quarter and year (for example, QI 1970).
Displays seconds (for example, 00).
Displays a date in the m/dd/yyyy format (for example, 1/25/1970 AM).
Displays a date in the m/dd/yyyy, hh:mm format (for example, 1/25/1970, 12:00 AM).
Displays time in the hh:mm format (for example, “12:00 AM”).
Displays numbers as a thousand (1 000.11 → 1K).
Displays numbers as a trillion (1 000 000 000 000 → 1T).
Displays years (for example, 1970).

Lists values that specify the chart’s axis types.

Automatically detects the series’s data type and uses it to render the axis. For integer and float data types, displays numeric arguments/values divided by ticks. For other data types, displays discrete arguments/values that correspond to chart points.
The axis uses a continuous scale to display numeric and date-time values.
Displays discrete arguments/values that correspond to chart points.
Displays numeric arguments/values that grow exponentially. Each axis argument/value equals to the specified logarithm base raised to a power (for instance, 10⁻², 10⁻¹, 10⁰, 10¹, 10⁻², etc.).

summary.para: Lists values that specify how to group data rows.
Rows are grouped by the character that the column values start with.
Custom logic is used to group grid data.
For date/time columns, rows are grouped by the date part of their values. The time part is ignored.
For date/time columns, rows are grouped by the month part of their values.

For date/time columns, rows are combined into the following non-overlapping groups according to their date value as compared with today’s date: “Beyond Next Month”, “Next Month”, “Later this Month”, “Three Weeks Away”, “Two Weeks Away”, “Next Week”, “Today”, “Tomorrow”, “Yesterday”, “Sunday”, “Monday”, “Tuesday”, “Wednesday”, “Thursday”, “Friday”, “Saturday”, “Last Week”, “Two Weeks Ago”, “Three Weeks Ago”, “Earlier this Month”, “Last Month”, “Older”.
For date/time columns, rows are grouped by the year part of their values.
For date/time columns, this option is the same as the Date option. For non date/time columns, this option is the same as the Value option.

Rows are grouped by the column values.

summary.para: Stores information about the search box and is passed as the context parameter to the .
Returns the Grid object.
Specifies the search text.
Lists values that specify how the grid treats search words.
The search words are not treated separately. Only records that match the search text exactly are shown.
The search words are treated as individual conditions grouped by the AND logical operator. Only records that match all of the conditions are shown.
The search words are treated as individual conditions grouped by the OR logical operator. Records that match at least one of these conditions are shown.
Lists values that specify whether the Select All checkbox selects all rows on the current page or on all grid pages.
The Select All checkbox selects and deselects all rows on all grid pages. This mode changes to Mixed when the Grid is bound to a large data source.

The Select All checkbox selects and deselects all rows on the current grid page. An additional drop-down button displays a context menu that allows users to select and deselect all rows on all grid pages.

The Select All checkbox selects and deselects all rows on the current grid page. This mode changes to Mixed when the Grid is bound to a large data source and vertical virtual scrolling mode is activated.

Lists automatic value completion modes.
The autocomplete feature is disabled. A user should type each character into the edit box.

When a user enters a character in the empty edit box for the first time, the editor fills all the placeholders with the default values. 0 is the default character for placeholders that accept numeric values. For placeholders that accept letters, a is the default character.

Each time a user types a character, the editor determines if the following placeholder can be filled. If only one character matches the mask, the editor displays this character and moves the caret forward.

summary.para: Lists values that specify display mode for the bar item’s text.
The item text is hidden by default, but displayed on mobile devices or when the item group is collapsed.
The item text is displayed by default, but hidden if there is not enough space to display all the bar items.
The item text is hidden.
Specifies vertical or horizontal orientation.
Sets horizontal orientation.
Sets vertical orientation.
Lists values that specify navigation modes for the Pager and Grid components.

The input box is displayed if the total number of pages is greater than or equal to the (for the Pager) or PagerSwitchToInputBoxButtonCount (for the Grid or TreeList), or the pager is shown on small devices. Otherwise, numeric buttons are displayed.
Users can type a page number in the displayed Go to Page input box to jump to the corresponding page.
Users can click numeric buttons to navigate between pages.
Lists extension modes for the component’s palette.
Repeats the full set of palette colors. Alternates normal, lightened, and darkened shades (in that order).
Blends two adjacent colors and inserts the new color between these colors in the palette.
Repeats the full set of palette colors. Gradually changes their shades from dark to light.
Specifies annotation position relative to the argument.
Positions an annotation at the center of a series slice.
Positions an annotation at the edge of a series slice.
Lists values that specify how a Pie Chart displays labels if they overlap.
Hides overlapping point labels.
Shows point labels in a stack formation. Applicable to series points that have the same argument.
Shows all point labels.
Lists values that specify how the chart arranges series slices.
Arranges series slices clockwise.
Arranges series slices counterclockwise.
Contains data for the event.

This option is in effect only for fields that store date/time values.Field values are grouped by the month part. Examples: January, February, March (the actual names of the months are determined by the current culture).
Unique field values are displayed as is.
This option is in effect only for fields that store date/time values.Field values are grouped by the quarterly intervals of the year. Each quarter includes three months. Examples: 1, 2, 3, and 4.
This option is in effect only for fields that store date/time values.Field values are grouped by the year. Examples: 2003, 2004, 2005.

summary.para: Lists values that specify a position of the label relative to the progress bar.
Displays the label below the progress bar.
Displays the label to the left of the progress bar.
Displays the label to the right of the progress bar.
Displays the label above the progress bar.
Lists values that specify progress bar status.
The progress bar displays a fully colored bar indicator and the Error label. Set this status to notify your users that there is an error in task progress.
The default status. The progress bar displays the extending bar indicator and the percentage progress value.
The progress bar displays a bar indicator at the current progress position and a Pause label. Set this status to notify your users that there is a delay in task progress.

The progress bar displays a fully colored bar indicator and the Success label. If the property is not specified, the component automatically sets the Success status when the reaches the . You can set the property to false to disable this behavior and set the status manually when the task is completed (in the event handler).
Lists values that specify a progress bar’s types.
Displays the circular progress bar.
Displays the horizontal progress bar.
Displays the vertical progress bar.
Lists values that specify how to arrange Radio Group items.
Sets the horizontal orientation.

Lists values that specify how the and components load tab content.
The component renders the content of all tabs in the DOM and maintains the tab’s state. This mode speeds up navigation between tabs, but can increase memory consumption.

The component initially loads only content of an active tab. When a user selects another tab, its content replaces the content of the previously active tab in the DOM. Note the component does not keep the tab’s state.

The component initially loads content of an active tab, then loads the content of other tabs when a user selects them. In this case, the component maintains the tab’s state. Use this mode to improve performance of your application.
Lists values that specify how users navigate between tabs when they do not fit the container’s width.
This scroll mode automatically adapts to the device type. Mobile and tablet devices use Swipe mode. Desktop devices use NavButtons mode.

The container displays tabs that fit the width. Users can navigate to other tabs in the following ways: use the navigation buttons; hover the cursor over a tab with the Shift key pressed and scroll the mouse wheel; or swipe (mobile devices only).
Users cannot scroll tabs. The tabs that do not fit the container’s width are moved to a new line.
The container displays a few tabs that fit the width. To navigate to other tabs, users can swipe tabs, or hover the mouse pointer over the container, hold the Shift key, and scroll the mouse wheel.
